So, boiling juice story....When I was in college I took a Roman Life course, and as a project made some Roman food. The most iconic Roman food? Garum--fermented fish sauce. The traditional way to make this involves putting fish, salt, and herbs in jars in the Mediterranean sun for several months. The quick way to make it involves boiling down grape juice to 10% its original volume and adding anchovy paste "to taste". I did this twice--once for practice, and once for an actual grade.

This had three results.

First, I can no longer drink grape juice. MY throat literally starts closing, and I will vomit by the second sip.

Second, I am no longer allowed to cook inside my parents' house.

Third: When I presented this to the class my professor said "Anyone who would do this to their professor is either going to get an A or an F." Apparently he liked it; I got an A.

If anyone is actually interested, the cloudy apple juice is made by actually mashing and squeezing raw apples in a press and collecting the juice as it drains out. It is probably pasterized but isn't boiled or filtered.
Clear juice is made from mashed and steamed apples. The juice is poured off after a settling period and is filtered, bottled, capped and heat/pressure sealed. It's almost a completely different product.

I'm always amused by the American term 'Apple Cider'. Cider, which has been made in most parts of the UK for at least a thousand years, is fermented apple juice, which can be mind-buggeringly alcoholic. That's what Cider is. Apples. It's only in the last few years that drinks have been made called 'Cider' but with other fruit flavours. Strictly, Cider is Apples. The drink that the Americans call 'Apple Cider' is actually a hot spiced punch that, in years past, would be made with alcoholic Cider, herbs, spices, etc., and served from a 'Wassail Bowl', as the drink was called 'Wassail'. And the drink you get from fermented pears is not Cider, by the way. It's called 'Perry'.
